title: Attributes

version_changes.summary: Massive increase in attribute usage due to FFI layer expansion. #[repr] increased 160% (197->512), #[no_mangle] introduced (602), #[derive] increased 52% (658->998), #[cfg] increased 140% (150->360). #![no_std] usage dramatically increased (2->23) for no_std support.
key_changes: #![no_std] increased from 2 to 23 (+1050%) for no_std support

summary: FLS Chapter 13 defines attributes as general, free-form metadata interpreted based on name, convention, language, and tool. iceoryx2 v0.8.0 makes extensive use of built-in attributes with major increases due to the FFI layer. Key additions include #[no_mangle] (602 instances) for C bindings and expanded #[repr(C)] usage (393 instances) for FFI type compatibility.

samples.purpose: Outer attributes enabling Clippy lints to enforce no_std compatibility in CAL crate

Outer attribute for conditional compilation based on feature flags

findings.description: Runtime attributes (#[global_allocator], #[panic_handler]) are only used in examples directory, not in production library code. Production crates use default allocator and panic behavior.
#[global_allocator] is only used in examples (nostd examples), not in production library code. Production code uses the default allocator.
#[panic_handler] is only used in examples (nostd examples), not in production library code. Production code uses default panic behavior.
Testing attributes (#[test], #[should_panic], #[ignore]) are by definition only used in test code, not production code. Statistics reflect test suite coverage.
#[ignore] is a testing attribute only used in test code, not production code.
#[should_panic] is a testing attribute only used in test code, not production code.
#[test] is a testing attribute only used in test code, not production code.
